bibl.title: Newspaper clipping, [New York City Register], September 27, 1900

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [New York City Register], September 27, 1900
div1.opener:
p 6
TELEPHONE, 1118-19TH ST.
Intended for Olin
“O wad some power the giftie gi'e us
To see oursel's as ithers see us.”
HENRY ROMEIKE,
110 Fifth Avenue,
Cable Address,
“ROMEIKE,” NEW YORK.
NEW YORK.
The First Established and Most Complete
Newspaper Cutting Bureau in the World.
Cutting from REGISTER
Address of Paper
New York Ci
Date Sep 27 1900
div1.p:
Washington, Sept. 27.--The adjutant
general has received a telegram saying
that Jesse W. Lazear, acting assistant
surgeon, died from yellow fever in Colum-
bia barracks, Havana. Dr. Lazear was a
resident of Baltimore and had only been
connected with the military establish-
ment a short time.
